problem: Consider the functions $p(x) = x - 2$ and $q(x) = 3x + 1$. Find the value of $p(q^{-1}(p^{-1}(q(p(4)))))$.
solution: First, find $p(4) = 4 - 2 = 2$. Then, $q(p(4)) = q(2) = 3*2 + 1 = 7$. Next, find the inverse of $p$, which is $p^{-1}(x) = x + 2$, so $p^{-1}(7) = 7 + 2 = 9$. Now, find the inverse of $q$, which is $q^{-1}(x) = (x - 1)/3$, so $q^{-1}(9) = (9 - 1)/3 = 8/3$. Finally, calculate $p(q^{-1}(9)) = p(8/3) = 8/3 - 2 = 2/3$, so $p(q^{-1}(p^{-1}(q(p(4))))) = \boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$.
